description: From Middle English concubine (first attested 1250–1300), from Anglo-Norman concubine, from Latin concubīna, equivalent to concub- (variant stem of concumbō (“to lie together”)) + feminine suffix -īna.

entries.meaning: A sexual partner, especially a woman, to whom one is not or cannot be married.
examples: Synonyms: mistress, sprunk; see also Thesaurus:sexual partner, Thesaurus:mistress

entries.meaning: A woman who lives with a man, but who is not a wife.
(chiefly historical) A slave-girl or woman, kept for instance in a harem, who is held for sexual service.
